DES NATIONSQUATRIEME COMMISSION DE L'ASSEMBLEE.RAPPORT SUR LA REPARTITION DES DEPENSES DE LA SOCIETE DES NATIONS.Conformement a la Recommandation adoptee par 1'Assemblee en decembre 1920, une Commission de cinq membres a ete nommee par le Conseil en vue de pre-senter uh rapport sur la repartition des depenses. (Ette Commission comprenait MM Reveillaud (France), President; Barboza Carneiro (Bresil); Alfred Georg (Suisse) Sthyr, puis de Kauffmanu, remplacant M. Gluckstadt (Daneniark) et Sir Henry Strakosch (Afrique du Sud). Le rapport devait etre soumis au Conseil avant le 31 mars 1921. La Commission des experts ne disposait done que de ties peu de temps pour etudier une question particulierement complexe et difficile. II lui etait mate-riellement impossible d'examiner a fond toutes les bases possibles de repartition, permettarit d'evaluer d'une maniere equitable k la capacite de paiement m des diffe-rents Membres de la Societe, selon le principe general approuve par la Commis-sion de la Conference Financiere de-Bruxelles.La Commission des experts n'avait pas a sa disposition de statistiques com-pletes relatives aux'revenus nationaux: obligee de presenter une proposition pra-tique avant 3 mois, elle a adopte comme mesure de la capacite de paiement 1'index de la population au 31 decembre 1919 et le revenu net de 1913, 1'annee precedant la guerre. La Commission des experts s'est parfaitement rendue compte que ces deux indices sont loin de constituer une base complete et sure pour la repartition projetee. Elle a reconnu, par exemple, que la population indigene considerable de certains pays situes hors d'Europe ri'augmente que dans une proportion infime les ressources de ces pays. Elle a done decide que pour aucun Etat, le coefficient de la population ne serait considere comme depassant 5 % de 1'ensemble de la population des Etats Membres de la Societe. La Commission a reconnu egalement combien il etait difficile de determiner le chiffre du revenu net. Elle a pris pour principe d'ajou-ter au revenu total provenant des impots, sans faire entrer en ligne les frais de re-- couvrement, le produit de ce que Ton pourrait appeler les services commerciaux de 1'Etat (chemins de fer, domaines, service postal, etc.) defalcation faite des depenses d'exploitation.Le retard qu'aurait entraine la recherche de documents et de statistiques nouvelles pour etablir la proportion exacte des depenses generales et locales dans les budgets des differents Etats constituant un Etat federal, a oblige la Commis-Sion des experts a n"e pas tenir compte de cette consideration dansTestimation du revenu net. Plusieurs Membres de la iv Commission ont attire 1'attention sur cette omission, qui a leur avis, compromet serieusement 1'equite des indices adoptes. En outre, oh pouvait presenter des objections au choix de la seule annee 1913 ou de toute autre d'ailleurs, pour detetminer le revenu net: ainsi, dans certains pays)le revenu depend des importations et des exportations et celles-ci varient dans de grandes proportions sous rinfluence de differents facteurs, tels que la qualite de la recolte. Afin de tenii compte de la situation differente qui peut en resulter pour un certain nombie de pays, il serait plus satisfaisant de prendre comme base la: moyenne du revenu net de plusieurs annees.. Enfin, 1'instabilite des changes et les troubles de la situation economique en general, ne pouvaieht etre ignores. Par consequent, des propositions s'appuyant sur les indices adoptes ne pouvaient etre considerees que comme ayant un caractere approximatif et provisoire et la Commission des experts a, dans son rapport, plei-nement reconnu toutes les imperfections d'un systeme qui n'a ete juge le seul prati-que qu'en raison du peu de temps dont on disposait. Toutefois, elle apu se rendre compte, en comparant avec certaines autres statistiques, que les resultats de ses travaux etaient sumsamment exacts. LEAGUE OF NATIONSFOURTH COMMITTEE OF THE ASSEMBLY.REPORT ON THE ALLOCATION OF THE EXPENSES OF THE LEAGUE OF NATIONS.In execution of the recommendation, adopted by the Assembly of the League of Nations in December, 1920, a Committee of five Members was appointed by the Council to report on the allocation of expenses. It was composed of MM. Reveillaud (France), Chairman; Barboza Carneiro (Brazil); Alfred Georg (Switzerland).; Sthyr, and subsequently de Kauffmann, as substitute.for, M. Gluckstadt (Denmark); and Sir Henry Strakosch (South Africa). The Report was to be presented to the Council by March, 31st 1921. The time at the disposal of this Committee in which to deal with so difficult and complex a question was, therefore, extremely short. It, was obviously beyond its powers thoroughly to investigate all possible. bases of allocation which might contribute to forming a fair estimate of the " capacity for payment" of the various Members of the League, which was the guiding principle approved by a Committee of the Brussels Financial Conference.Adequate statistics of national resources were not available, and the-Committee', faced with the obligation of submitting a practical proposal within three months, adopted as a measure of the capacity for payment the index obtainable from totals of populations on December, 31st 1919, in conjunction with the net revenue for 1913, the last year before the war. The Expert Committee readily admitted that both these indices must remain a far from complete or reliable basis for the. purpose in view. They recognised, for instance, that the large native populations of cer- -tain extra European countries do not, in many eases, appreciably increase their resources.. It was therefore laid down that the co-efficient of the population of any State should in no case be estimated as exceeding 5 per cent of the total popula-tion of the States Members of the League. No less readily did the Expert Com-mittee admit the difficulties which arose in determining the amount which could, properly be ascribed to net revenue. The principle adopted was to add to the gross revenue derived from taxation, without taking into account the cost of collection, the amounts derived from what may be described as the trading departments of a State, (railways, domains, postal service etc.) from which administrative and running expenses were deducted..The very long delay which would have been entailed by the collection of docu-ments and evidence to establish the due proportion of local and general expenditure in the Budgets of individual components of a Federal State, made it inevitable, under the circumstances, that this consideration should be ignored in the estimates of net revenue adopted by the Expert Committee. Several Members of the Fourth Committee have drawn attention to this omission as seriously impairing the justice of the actual indices adopted. There were, moreover, other considerations which might.be advanced against the adoption of the particular year 1913, coi-indeed of any single year, for the determination of net revenue, such as the fact that the revenue depending on imports and exports in certain countries fluctuates very considerably according to the quality of the harvests. To meet the varying cir-cumstances of a number of countries, an average of the revenue of a series of years would provide a more satisfactory basis..Finally, the unstable character of exchanges, and the general disturbance of economic conditions at the present moment, -could not be overlooked. Proposals exclusively based upon the indices adopted could not therefore be regarded as other then approximate and provisional, and the defects in the system, which was found, to be the only practical one to adopt in view of the brief time, available, are fully, recognised, by the Expert Committee in their Report. They had, however, been, able to make comparisons with certain other statistical data which confirmed their view that the results of their labours were reasonably accurate.S. d. N. 13' 0. 9/21. Imp. Kundig La Commission des experts a classe tous les pays Membres de la Societe selon un indice moyen resultant de Tindice k population n et' de 1'indice (( revenu net. o Elle a conserve le systeme adopte par 1'Union postale universelle, c'est-a-dire le groupement des Etats par categories: ce systeme d'ailleurs permettait egalement de tenir compte d'autres facteurs que les deux indices ci-dessus mentionnes. Toutefois, elle est arrived a la conclusion que la repartition meme adoptee pour 1'Union postale universelle et prescrite a 1'article 6 du Pacte de la SocieTe^ comme base de repartition des contributions, ne pouvait etre appliquee d'une maniere equita-ble et qu'il eTait necessaire de la modifier pour eviter de l&er certains Membres. D'autre part, les regies auxquelles est soumise 1'Union postale universelle ne per-mettraient pas d'aboutir a une modification a la classification actuelle avant au moins un an et peut-etre dix-huit mois et par ailleurs, les modifications proposees par la Commission des experts pourraient constituer un obstacle a la ratification par 1'Union postale, des amendements proposes. Pour ces motifs, la Commission a declare que le projet de repartition des depenses ne pouvait etre realise que par voie d'amende-ment a 1'article 6 du Pacte. L'Assemblee se trouverait ainsi liberee de 1'obligation d'appliquer strictement le systeme de TUnion postale universelle.La nouvelle repartition proposee figure au tableau II annexe au rapport de la Commission des experts (A. 40-1921). Toutefois, etant donne les difncultes et les re-tards que doit entrainer une modification au Pacte', la Commission, outie ce projet qui, selon ses-vues, pourrait etre applique jusqu'au momeht ou des enquetes complementaires permettraient d'apprecier plus exactement la situation econo-mique, a presente egalement un Iprojet transitoire qu'elle pensait pouvoir etre realise, dans le cadre actuel du Pacte, et qui aurait permis, tout en conservant les indices essentiels de TUnion postale universelle, de soulager d'une facon consi-considerable les Etats inscrits actuellement dans une cat^gorie trop elevee. Ce projet de repartition provisoire figure au tableau III, du rapport de la Commission des Experts.Quand la iv Commission a commence la discussion des propositions exposees dans le rapport de la Commission des experts, on a pu constater, non seulement par des critiques orales, mais aussi par un certain nombre de resolutions presentees qu'une divergence d/opinion existait au sein de la Commission sur la question de savoir lequel des deux projets de repartition exposes au tableau II et au tableauTII, (tous deux d'ailleurs considered comme: des solutions provisoires), etait preferable. Toutefois, il a ete decide que la Commission ne serait invitee a exprimer son avis sur ce point qu'apres avoir procede a 1'etude de 1'aspect juridique de la question.Sur la proposition du President, la Commission a decide d'inviter la Ire Corn-mission, chargee d'etudier les amendements au Pacte, de designer, d'accord avec la iv Commission, une Sous-Commission mixte comprenant des juristes ejminents, chargee d'etudier le point de vue juridique et de presenter ses conclusions. La iv Commission a designe MM. Adatci (Japon), Fernandes (Bresil) et Trygger (Suede), avec Sir Reimell Rodd, rapporteur de la iv Commission; la Ire Commission a desi-gnele capitaine Bruce (Australie), MM. Noblemaire (France), Osuski (Tcheco-Slova-quie) et Zahle (Danemark) a titre de rapporteurs de la Ire Commission.Le delegue italien a declare que d'apres la Constitution de son pays, il ne pou-vait - accepter aucune proposition comportant un accroissement de contribution sans la sanction du Parlement. II ne pouvait done donner son adhesion a aucune augmentation de la somme fixee poui 1'Italie. conformement au Pacte, tant que la Parlement n'aurait pas ratifie un amendement a 1'article VI. D'autres deligues se sont exprimes dans le meme sens.Le delegue de la Pologne, parlant egalement au nom de la Roumanie, de la Tcheco-Slovaquie et de l'etat serbe-croate-slovene, souleva la question de savoir s'il conviendrait de tenir compte, dans la repartition des contributions, de la ques-tion du change qui, a Theure actuelle, a une influence si considerable sur la situation economique d'un certain nombre de Membres de la Societe. La iv Commission a decide, a la majoiite des voix, qu'il y/avait lieu, pour diverses raisons d'ordre pratique et technique, de ne pas tenir compte du change.II a ete decide^ en outre, de supprimer le classement par ordre numerique, qui avait cause certains malentendus et d'adopter le classement par ordre alphabe-tique. D'autres Membres de la iv Commission ont developp^ les critiques d6ja mentionnees plus haut, sur le caractere insuffisant ou incomplet des indices adoptes, ou ont attire 1'attention sur 1'absence de toute consideration des souf-frances que certains pays ont eu a supporter du fait de la guerre, ou sur le caractere quelque peu arbitraire du systeme de groupement, qui placait dans la meme cate- When a discussion of the proposals put forward in the Report of the Expert Committee was opened in the Fourth Committee, it at once became evident not only from the criticisms made orally, but also from a certain number of resolutions which were submitted, that a divergence of view existed as to whether the scheme of allo-cation set forth in Table II or that in Table III, both of which were regarded as only provisional solutions, was the more acceptable. It was, however, decided that the general sense of the Committee should not be taken on this question until the legal aspect of the situation had been examined. ., On the proposal of the Chairman it was decided to invite the First Committee, which has to deal with amendments to the Covenant, to join with the Fourth Com-mittee in appointing a mixed Sub-Committeedn which eminent juridical authorities should be included, to examine into, and report on, the legal position. On behalf of the Fourth Committee MM. Adatci (Japan), Fernandes (Brazil) and Trygger (Sweden) were selected to act togethei with Sir Rennel Rodd,. the reporter to the Fourth Committee; on behalf of the First Committee, Captain Bruce (Australia), MM. Noblemaire (France), Osusky (Czecho-Slovakia), with M. Zahle (Denmark) as reporter to the First Committee.The Italian Delegate took the opportunity of announcing that, by the consti-tution of Italy, he was precluded from accepting any proposal involving an increased contribution without the sanction of Parliament. He could not therefore assent to any augmentation in the amount allocated to Italy under the Covenant until after the ratification of -Parliament had been obtained to an amendment of Article VI. Other Delegates expressed similar views.The question whether exchange, which at the present moment so seriously affects the economic situation of certain Members of the League, should be taken into account in determining the allocation of contributions was raised by the Dele-gate of Poland, who in this matter spoke also on behalf of Roumania, Czecho-Slova-kia, and the Serb-Croat-Slovene State. The Fourth Committee decided, by a majority resolution, that for various reasons of a practical and technical character the consideration of exchange must be excluded. - -It was further decided that the numerical order of the groups into which the countries Members of the League were- divided, which had led to misapprehensions, should be discontinued, and that countries should be arranged in alphabetical order. ...Other Members of the Fourth Committee supplemented the criticisms to which reference has already been made, such as the incompleteness or insufficiency, of the indices adopted, by drawing attention to the absence of any specialThe Committee of Experts proceeded to classify all the countries Members of the League in accordance with a mean index number obtained from the two factors of population and revenue. It maintained the system adopted by the Universal Postal Union of grouping the States into categories a system which, incidentally allowed some account to be taken of other factors "than the two mentioned above. It concluded, however, that the apportionment adopted for the Universal Postal Union, which is prescribed by Article VI of the Covenant of the League of Nations as the basis of allocation of contributions, could not equitably be applied, and that it was indispensable to modify it in order to prevent injustice being done to the Members. On the other hand, the rules of the Universal Postal Union made it clear that no alteration of its classification could be brought about in less than a year or eighteen months, while there was a probability that the alterations advocates-cated by the Expert Committee would themselves prove an obstacle to acceptance of Amendments by the Postal Union. The Expert Committee therefore submitted that the scheme which.they recommended for the allocation of expenses could only be introduced by an Amendment in Article VI of the Covenant. Such an Amend-ment would liberate the Assembly from the obligation of strictly applying the system of the Universal Postal Union.The proposed new. allocation will be found in Table II annexed to the Report of the Expert Committee (A. 40,1921). In view, however, of the difficulties and delays which an alteration of the Covenant must entail, the Expert Committee, in addition to this proposed allocation, which might hold good until further inves-tigations enabled all the facts of the economic situation to be more precisely esta-established, also submitted a transitional proposal which, it is believed, might be adopted within the present limits of the Covenant, provisionally maintaining the elemental indices of the Universal Postal Union, while at the- same time relieving to a considerable extent the States actually included in too high a group. -The provisional allocation is set forth in Table III annexed to the Report of the Expert Committee. gorie, des pays dont les chiffres indices pr&entaient des differences considerables, et dont la situation economique n'etait pas absolument comparable.Cependaiit, la iv Commission reconnaissant les difficultes auxquelles b'est heurtee la Commission des experts et l'impossibilite\ dans les conditions actuelles, d'aboutir a autre chose qu'a une repartition approximative, a tenu a temoigner a cette Commission sa'haute appreciation de dceuvre qu'elle a accOmplie en si peu de temps, en presentant un rapport unanime et en soumettant une proposition de nouvelle repartition qui, de 1'avis general, tend, dans ses gran des lignes, a redresser les inegalites manifestes du bareme actuel.. La SouS-Commission mixte de la Ire et de la iv Commission, apres plusieurs seances, a exprime a 1'unanimite 1'opinion que le bareme de repartition actuelle-ment en vigueur ne pourrait etre modifie que par un amendement au Pacte. Le tableau transitoire N0 III, presente dans le rapport de la Commission des experts, n'offrait pas mieux que le tableau n0 II de solution provisoire dans le cadre du Pacte.' En consequence, la Sous-Commission a suggere 1'amendement suivant au Pacte:i. En vertu de 1'article 5 du Pacte cettc Resolution devra etre prise a l'unanimite.((Toutefois, comme 1'Assemblee ne pourra user de sa nouvelle faculte ' qu'apres la ratification de 1'amendement intervenue de la maniere prevue a 1'article 26 du Pacte, et comme il est d'autre part absolument necessaire de modifier a une date aussi rapprochee que possible le bareme actuel de 1'Union Postale Universelle que la premiere Assemblee a deja reconnu comme peu equitable, la Sous-Commission a ete d'avis que la modification de l'article 6 du Pacte devrait etre completee par un article transitoire ayant la meme force que le Pacte et partant sounds a la procedure de 1'article 26 du Pacte. ,11 est clair que cet article transitoire, lui aussi,. ne pourra entrer en vigueur que dans le courant de et 1'entree en vigueur de 1'artile transitoire, les choses^pourraient, dans 1'opinion de la Sous-Commissioi', se passer de la maniere suivante: En Janvier 1922, epoque a laquelle le Diiecteur, des Finances devra notifier aux Membres de la Societe les sommes a vefser par.eux pour le service de 1922, nous nous trouverons tres probablement encore &ous le regime du bareme existant, celui de 1'Union postale.k Le Directeur des Finances devrait done faire connaitre aux Membres de la Socicte leur quote-part basee sur ce bareme-la, mais rien ne l'empecherait consideration for the countries which had suffered most heavily by the war, and to the somewhat arbitrary nature of the grouping system, which placed in the same cate-gory countries whose index figures differed widely, and whose economic situation' was not comparable.The Fourth Committee, however, realising the difficulties which had been encountered and the impossibility of arriving under the circumstances at more than an approximate adjustment, expressed their high appreciation of the remark-able achievement of the Expert Committee which had, within so brief a period, succeeded in presenting an unanimous report. and submitting a proposal for the readjustment of contributions which, it was generally admitted, in its main out-lines went far to correct the manifest injustices of the existing scale.Thev joint Sub-Committee of the First and Fourth Committees after several meetings expressed the unanimous opinion that the actual scale of allocation in force could not be modified without amending the Covenant. The Transitional Table III submitted in the Report of the expert Committee was, in this respect, in precisely the same position as Table II, and did not offer a provisional solution within the limits of the Covenant.The Sub-Committee accordingly suggested the following amendments to the Covenant:. "i. The last paragraph of Article VI of the Covenant shall be replaced by the following:"The expenses of the League shall be borne by the Members.of the League in the proportion decided by the Assembly. "2. Provisional Article (to be inserted as an Annex to the Covenant).. "The following allocation of the expenses of the League shall be applied as from January ist, 1922. "(Insert the Table to be adopted by Committee No. 4),The following considerations were added in the Report of the joint Sub-Com-mitfee:"By the new paragraph of Article VI of the Covenant the Sub-Committee . adopts the proposal of the Committee dealing with amendments to the Cove-nant, according to which the Assembly would have the power to determine the scale simply by a Resolution and not by the procedure laid down in Article 26 of the Covenant. In accordance with Article 5 of the Covenant this Reso-lution will have to be accepted unanimously." Nevertheless, as the Assembly will be unable to make use of its new faculty until the amendment shall have been ratified, as prescribed in Article 26 of the Covenant; and as, on the other hand, it is absolutely necessary that the inequity, already recognised by the First Assembly, of the present scale of the Universal Postal Union should be modified as soon as possible, the Sub-Com-mittee was of opinion that Amendment of Article 6 of the Covenant should be supplemented by a provisional article, possessing the same validity as the Covenant, and being subject to the stipulations prescribed in Article 26 of the Covenant. It is obvious that this temporary articlewill only become effective during the course of the year 1922, but once it has become effective, the scale to which it refers will become operative as from January ist, 1922, and conse-quently will cover the whole financial year 1922."The Sub-Committee is of. opinion that'the matter can be arranged in the following manner between January ist, 1922, and the date when the provi-sional article becomes effective. In January' 1922 when the director of the Financial Administration has to notify to the Members of the League the amounts which they are required to pay for the expenses of 1922, we shall most probably find that we are still under the existing scale of the Universal Postal Union, and the Director of the Financial Administration should there-fore inform the Members of the League of the amount of their contribution . according to this scale. But there is no reason why the Director should not d'ajouter le montant que les Membres devraient payer en vertu du nouveau bareme.
